title: Barrister2 Documentation Site
description:
# Barrister2 Documentation Site

Comprehensive documentation site for Barrister2 hosted on GitHub Pages with Jekyll and Lunr.js search.

## Overview

Create complete documentation including:
- Installation guide (4 methods)
- E-commerce checkout example IDL
- Language-specific quickstarts for all 5 supported languages (Go, Java, Python, TypeScript, C#)
- IDL reference guide (syntax, types, validation)
- Working code examples with automated testing
- GitHub Actions deployment pipeline

## Tech Stack

- **Jekyll 4.x** - Static site generator (GitHub Pages native)
- **Lunr.js** - Client-side search
- **GitHub Pages** - Hosting via `gh-pages` branch
- **GitHub Actions** - CI/CD pipeline

## Quickstart Example: E-Commerce Checkout

The example demonstrates:
- 3 interfaces: CatalogService, CartService, OrderService
- 5 enums/structs: Product, Cart, Order, Address, PaymentMethod
- Custom error codes (1001-1005): cart_not_found, cart_empty, payment_failed, out_of_stock, invalid_address

## Success Criteria

1. Documentation site builds locally with `bundle exec jekyll serve`
2. All code examples run successfully via test scripts
3. Quickstart guides are complete and copy-pasteable
4. Search works via Lunr.js
5. Site deploys to GitHub Pages via GitHub Actions
6. CI tests all examples and prevents broken docs
7. All 5 supported languages have complete quickstarts

---

**Source:** Implementation plan docs/plans/2026-01-13-documentation-plan.md
**Design:** docs/plans/2026-01-13-documentation-design.md

title: Create Jekyll site structure
description:
# Create Jekyll site structure Create the foundational Jekyll site files and configuration. ## Files to create 1. **`docs/_config.yml`** - Jekyll configuration: ```yaml title: Barrister2 RPC description: IDL-based JSON-RPC code generation lang: en baseurl: /barrister2 markdown: kramdown highlighter: rouge plugins: - jekyll-seo-tag - jekyll-sitemap exclude: - Gemfile - Gemfile.lock - node_modules - vendor/bundle collections: pages: output: true permalink: /:path/ ``` 2. **`docs/_layouts/default.html`** - Main layout: ```html {{ site.title }} | {{ page.title }} {% include header.html %}
{{ content }}
{% include footer.html %} ``` 3. **`docs/_includes/header.html`** - Site header with basic navigation: ```html

{{ site.title }}

  • Get Started
  • IDL Guide
  • Languages
``` 4. **`docs/_includes/footer.html`** - Site footer: ```html

© 2024 Barrister2. Built with Jekyll.

``` 5. **`docs/index.md`** - Landing page with project overview 6. **`docs/assets/css/styles.css`** - Basic styling 7. **`docs/Gemfile`** - Ruby dependencies: ```ruby source "https://rubygems.org" gem "jekyll", "~> 4.3" gem "jekyll-seo-tag" gem "jekyll-sitemap" ``` ## Verification Run `bundle exec jekyll serve` in `/docs` directory - site should serve at http://localhost:4000 ## Expected outcome - Jekyll site builds without errors - Basic navigation works - Landing page displays
design:
## Design Context

**Goal:** Create foundational Jekyll site structure to serve as the base for all documentation.

**Tech Stack:** Jekyll 4.x (GitHub Pages native static site generator)

**Architecture:**
- Uses Kramdown for markdown processing
- Rouge for syntax highlighting
- SEO and sitemap plugins for discoverability
- Clean layout structure with header/footer includes

**Why this approach:**
- Jekyll is GitHub Pages native (zero config deployment)
- Component-based includes allow reuse across pages
- Collections enable flexible content organization
acceptance_criteria: Jekyll site builds locally with 'bundle exec jekyll serve' and serves at http://localhost:4000; basic navigation works between pages; landing page displays correctly

title: Write installation guide
description:
## File: docs/get-started/installation.md

Content:
1. Prerequisites (Go 1.21+, or pre-built binary)
2. Four installation methods:
   - Go install: 'go install github.com/bitmechanic/barrister2@latest'
   - Download binary from Releases
   - Docker: 'docker pull ghcr.io/bitmechanic/barrister2:latest'
   - Build from source: 'make build'
3. Verification: 'barrister --version'
4. Troubleshooting section (PATH, Go version, permissions)
design: Goal: Clear installation instructions for all users. Multiple methods accommodate different workflows.
acceptance_criteria: Users can install Barrister using any of 4 methods; instructions are clear and copy-pasteable; troubleshooting covers common issues

title: Write quickstart overview
description:

title: Implement Lunr.js search
design:
## Design Context

**Goal:** Provide fast client-side search across all documentation pages.

**Tech Stack:** Lunr.js - JavaScript full-text search library

**Why Lunr.js:**
- No server-side search infrastructure needed
- Fast full-text search with relevance scoring
- Works perfectly with static sites
- Small footprint, CDN available

**Architecture:**
- Index built client-side on page load from Jekyll page data
- Real-time search as user types
- Shows page title and snippet
acceptance_criteria: Typing in search box shows matching pages; search works on all markdown content; search results are clickable links

title: Create Python docs test
description:
## File: tests/integration/test-docs-python.sh

```bash
#\!/bin/bash
set -e
cd docs/examples/checkout-python
python3 server.py &
SERVER_PID=$\!
sleep 2
python3 client.py
kill $SERVER_PID
```
design: Goal: Test Python example to prevent broken docs.
acceptance_criteria: Script is executable; running script successfully tests the Python example; exits 0 on success, non-zero on failure

title: Create Go docs test
description:
## File: tests/integration/test-docs-go.sh

```bash
#\!/bin/bash
set -e
cd docs/examples/checkout-go/server
go run main.go &
SERVER_PID=$\!
sleep 2
cd ../client
go run main.go
kill $SERVER_PID
```
design: Goal: Test Go example to prevent broken docs.
acceptance_criteria: Successfully tests Go example; clean shutdown of server

## File: tests/integration/test-docs-all.sh

```bash
#\!/bin/bash
set -e
echo 'Testing Python docs example...'
tests/integration/test-docs-python.sh
echo 'Testing Go docs example...'

echo 'Testing Java docs example...'
tests/integration/test-docs-java.sh
```

title: Create GitHub Actions workflow
description:
## File: .github/workflows/docs.yml

Full workflow with:
- Trigger on push to main with paths: [docs/**]
- Install Go and build Barrister
- Test all 5 language docs examples
- Setup Ruby and install Jekyll deps
- Build Jekyll site
- Deploy to gh-pages branch using peaceiris/actions-gh-pages@v3
design: Goal: CI/CD pipeline to test docs and deploy to GitHub Pages.
acceptance_criteria: Pushing to main triggers the workflow; all docs examples are tested; Jekyll site builds successfully; site deploys to GitHub Pages

title: Create navigation structure
description:
# Create navigation structure

Create all placeholder documentation pages with proper navigation.

## Files to create/update

1. **Update `docs/_includes/header.html`** - Add dropdown navigation for all sections

2. **Create placeholder pages:**
   - `docs/get-started/installation.md`
   - `docs/get-started/quickstart-overview.md`
   - `docs/idl-guide/syntax.md`
   - `docs/idl-guide/types.md`
   - `docs/idl-guide/validation.md`
   - `docs/languages/go/install.md`
   - `docs/languages/go/quickstart.md`
   - `docs/languages/go/reference.md`
   - (Repeat for java, python, typescript, csharp)

Each page should have:
```markdown
---
title: [Page Title]
# [Page Title]

Coming soon...
```

## Verification

- Navigation menu with dropdowns works
- All pages are accessible via nav
- Each page has proper title in browser tab
design:
## Design Context

**Goal:** Establish complete site navigation structure with all pages as placeholders.

**Architecture:** Language-centric organization - users can jump to their preferred language

**Navigation hierarchy:**
- Get Started (Installation, Quickstart Overview)
- IDL Guide (Syntax, Types, Validation)
- Languages (Go, Java, Python, TypeScript, C# - each with Install, Quickstart, Reference)
acceptance_criteria: Navigation menu with dropdowns works; all pages are accessible via nav; each page has proper title and breadcrumbs

title: Create custom code_file plugin
description:
# Create custom code_file plugin

Implement custom Liquid tag to embed source files in markdown.

## File to create

**`docs/_plugins/code_file.rb`:**
```ruby
module Jekyll
  class CodeFile < Liquid::Tag
    def initialize(tag_name, markup, tokens)
      super
      @path = markup.strip
    end

    def render(context)
      site = context.registers[:site]
      file_path = File.join(site.source, @path)
      if File.exist?(file_path)
        contents = File.read(file_path)
        syntax = file_path.split('.').last
        # Map extensions to syntax highlighter names
        syntax_map = {
          'py' => 'python',
          'go' => 'go',
          'java' => 'java',
          'ts' => 'typescript',
          'cs' => 'csharp',
          'rb' => 'ruby',
          'js' => 'javascript'
        }
        syntax = syntax_map[syntax] || syntax
        "```#{syntax}\n#{contents}\n```"
      else
        "_Error: File not found: #{@path}_"
      end
    end
  end
end

Liquid::Template.register_tag('code_file', Jekyll::CodeFile)
```

## Usage in markdown

```markdown
{% code_file examples/checkout-python/server.py %}
```

## Verification

- Using `{% code_file path/to/file.py %}` in markdown embeds file contents with syntax highlighting
- Missing files show helpful error message
- Jekyll builds without errors
design:
## Design Context

**Goal:** Enable embedding working source code directly into documentation.

**Why this approach:**
- Code lives as runnable source files, not copy-pasted in markdown
- Tests validate code works, preventing documentation rot
- Single source of truth for examples
- Changes to examples automatically reflected in docs

**Architecture:** Custom Jekyll plugin reads files at build time and embeds them with proper syntax highlighting.
acceptance_criteria: Using '{% code_file path/to/file.py %}' in markdown embeds file contents with syntax highlighting; missing files show helpful error message

title: Create checkout.idl
description:
# Create checkout.idl

Create the e-commerce checkout IDL that will be used for all quickstart examples.

## File to create

**`examples/checkout.idl`:**

Full IDL from design document with:
- Namespace: `checkout`
- Enums: OrderStatus, PaymentMethod
- Structs: Product, CartItem, Cart, Address, Order, AddToCartRequest, CreateOrderRequest, CheckoutResponse
- Interfaces: CatalogService, CartService, OrderService
- Error codes documented (1001-1005)

See design document for complete IDL.

## Verification

- IDL compiles successfully with `./target/barrister checkout.idl`
- Covers all IDL features: namespace, interface, struct, enum, optional fields, arrays
design:
## Design Context

**Goal:** Create a realistic, comprehensive IDL that demonstrates all Barrister2 features.

**Why E-commerce checkout:**
- Familiar domain (everyone understands shopping)
- Rich data modeling (products, carts, orders, payments)
- Multiple service boundaries (catalog, cart, order)
- Natural error scenarios (out of stock, payment failed)

**IDL Features Demonstrated:**
- All built-in types (string, int, float, bool)
- Optional fields
- Arrays
- Struct inheritance
- Custom error codes (1001-1005)
acceptance_criteria: IDL compiles successfully with './target/barrister checkout.idl'; covers all IDL features (namespace, interface, struct, enum, optional fields, arrays)

title: Validate checkout.idl with all runtimes
description:
# Validate checkout.idl with all runtimes

Generate code for all 5 supported languages from checkout.idl.

## Commands to run

```bash
./target/barrister -runtime go-client-server examples/checkout.idl
./target/barrister -runtime java-client-server examples/checkout.idl
./target/barrister -runtime python-client-server examples/checkout.idl
./target/barrister -runtime ts-client-server examples/checkout.idl
./target/barrister -runtime csharp-client-server examples/checkout.idl
```

## Verification

- All 5 languages generate successfully
- No syntax errors or validation errors
- Generated files compile/run in their respective environments
design:
## Design Context

**Goal:** Ensure checkout.idl is valid across all supported Barrister2 runtimes.

**Why:** The IDL must work for all language quickstarts. Validating early prevents issues during implementation.

**Validation:** Each runtime has its own code generator, so we test all of them.
acceptance_criteria: All 5 languages generate successfully from checkout.idl; no syntax errors or validation errors; generated files compile in their respective environments

title: Python quickstart example
description:
# Python quickstart example

Create working Python server and client for checkout example.

## Directory to create

**`docs/examples/checkout-python/`**

## Files to create

1. **`checkout.idl`** - Copy from examples/checkout.idl
2. **`server.py`** - Full server implementation:
   - Implements CatalogService, CartService, OrderService
   - In-memory storage using dicts
   - Error handling with codes 1001-1005
   - Starts HTTP server on localhost:8080

3. **`client.py`** - Full client implementation:
   - Calls listProducts, addToCart, createOrder
   - Demonstrates success case (valid order)
   - Demonstrates error case (e.g., empty cart → error 1002)
   - Prints readable output

4. **`README.md`** - Brief instructions

## Verification

- Running `python3 server.py` starts server without errors
- Running `python3 client.py` in another terminal produces expected output
- All three services work correctly
- Error codes are properly returned (1001-1005)
design:
## Design Context

**Goal:** Create complete working Python example demonstrating Barrister2 usage.

**Tech Stack:** Python 3, Barrister2 Python runtime

**Implementation:**
- In-memory dict storage for simplicity (no database needed)
- All 3 interfaces implemented
- Custom error codes demonstrate RPC error handling
- Copy-pasteable code for quickstart

**Why Python first:** Python is most readable, serves as reference for other languages.
acceptance_criteria: Running 'python3 server.py' starts server; 'python3 client.py' produces expected output; all three services work correctly; error codes 1001-1005 properly returned

title: Go quickstart example
description:
# Go quickstart example

Create working Go server and client for checkout example.

## Directory: `docs/examples/checkout-go/`

## Files:
- `idl/checkout.idl`
- `server/main.go` - Implements all interfaces with in-memory storage (maps + sync.Mutex)
- `server/go.mod`
- `client/main.go` - Demonstrates all service calls
- `client/go.mod`
- `README.md`

## Verification
- `go run server/main.go` starts server
- `go run client/main.go` produces expected output
- Code passes `go vet` and `gofmt`
design: Goal: Complete working Go example. Tech: Go 1.21+, Barrister2 Go runtime. Implementation: In-memory maps with mutex for concurrency.
acceptance_criteria: 'go run server/main.go' starts server; 'go run client/main.go' produces expected output; code passes 'go vet' and 'gofmt'
